With a sigh the sergeant dropped his eyes from the wall be could barely distin guish and, following Judge Ostranders lead, passed with him under the torn folds of the cùrtain and through the narrow vestibule whose door was made of iron, into the room where, in a stronger blaze of light than they had left, lay the body of the dead negro awaiting the last rites. Would the judge pass this body, or tarn away from it toward a door lead ing front? TJie sergeant had come in at thè rfear, but he greatly desired to go out front, as this would give him so much additional knowledge of the houee. Unexpectedly to  himself the judges Intentions were in the direc tion of hS own Wishes. He was led front and, entering an old-fashioned hall dimly lighted, passed a staircase and two closed doors, both of which gave him the impression of having been shut upon a past it had pleasured no one to revive in many years. Beyond them was the great front door of colonial style and workman shjp. a fine specimen once, but greatly disfigured now by the bolts and bars which had been added to it in satis faction of the judges ideas of security, Many years had passed since Judge Ostrander had played the host but he had not lost a sense of its obligations It was for him to shoot the -bolts and lift foe bars but be went about it so clumsily and with such evident aver sion to the task that the sergeant In stinctively sprang to help him. I shall miss Bela at every turn, remarked the judge, turning with a sad emlle as he finally pulled the door open. This is an unaccustomed effort for me. - Excuse my awkwardness. Something in his attitude, something in the way he lifted his hand to push, back a fallen lock from his forehead, impressed -itself upon the sergeants mind so vividly that he always re membered the judge as he appeared to him at that minute. Certainly there were but few men like him in the country, and none in his own town. Of a commanding personality by reason of his height, his features were of a cast to express his mental attributes and enforce attention, and the incongruity between his dominat ing figure and the apprehensions which he displayed in these multiplied and extraordinary arrangements for per sonal security was forcible enough to arouse any mans interest. The sergeant was so occupied by the mystery of the man and the mystery of the house that they had passed the first gate which the judge had un locked without much difficulty before hp realized that there still remained something of interest for him to see and to talk about later. document.text: Sergeant Jerry Simpson Beas ley The remains of Sergeant Jerry Simpson Beasley, who was killed in France on Oct. 4th, 1918, during the World War, arrived on Saturday last and were interred in the family cemetery at Hollywood on Sun day following. document.text: Roanoke.In a report handed in at midnight the special grand jury calls on Mayor Joel H. Cutchin to show why be should not be removed from office, charging him with collu sion with persons of ill repute and with haying accepted gifts of various kinds from these people. The report charges Police Sergeant Lemon with the same offense. Following the pre sentation of the report Judge Seaples announced that he would ask the Governor to appoint a judge to pre side in the case of Mayor Cutchin, which will be taken up at the next term of court. The text of the re port does not come as a surprise, since the Jine of examination follow ed by the jury had been talked of for some time. Mayor Cutchin has held office for many years and is 61 years old. Mayor Cutchin issued the follow ing statement The report of the special grand jury just published is such that I ask the public to withhold its judgment until after investigation and ask my friends to believe me Incapable of in tentional wrongdoing. I declare with all the interest of my soul that I am innocent, and before an honest and just judge that fact will be shown and the motives for my prosecution disclosed. The Mayor also issued an order suspending Police Sergeant Lemon, who was mentioned in the grand jury report. Suffolk.Seeking to sacrifice her brother, Prince Carr, in the hope of securing a pardon for her husband, Ethel Edmunds is accusing the for mer of attempted assassination, a crime for which the husband, Wil liam Edmunds, already has been sen tenced to two years in States prison. Shortly after the husband was con victed In the city Circuit Court the woman said Carr was guilty of the crime. He then had left the city, but was run down and was arraigned be fore Mayor Norfleet for a hearing and held. The assistant prosecutor for the State was aided by the two law yers of Edmunds counsel, who moved Carr to save their own client. Carr had no legal adviser. Taylor, captain and lieutenant of the First and Second Companies, Coast Artillery, recently disbanded by order of Governor Mann, the State of Virginia entered suits in the Court of Law and Chan cery. The suits resulted from the inability of thie two officers to account for the equipment of the companies furnished by the United States gov ernment and for which the State is responsible. Commonwealths Attor ney Tilton filed the suits. Leesburg.Decatur White, unmar ried, of a well-known family of Lou doun county, attempted to commit suicide at his home, near Leesburg. He first drank carbolic acid and then shot himself just below the heart with a .32-calibre revolver. Illness and despondency are given as the cause. He is a retired farmer and lives with his brother, Tobias White. He is not expected to recover. Hampton.John W. Leech, aged 70 years, a veteran of the Confed erate Army, committed suicide in Phoebus jail by hanging himself with Ian improvised rope made from his khaki shirt. Fastening one end of the shirt to the top of his cell and the other around his neck, he jumped from his bunk. His body when found hanging in the centre of the room was already lifeless. Fredericksburg.John M. W. Green, of this city, has sold a part of his fine farm in Stafford county, near this city, of 105 acres, on the east side, to Wil liam Rawson, of England. Mr. Raw- son will build a residence for his home and will make a number of improve ments. Harrisonburg.An automobile ran into a culvert five miles from town, turning over and injuring both occu pants. J. W. Thompson, postmaster of Dayton, was knocked unconscious and badly bruised. William Evers, of Day- ton, suffered similar injuries, losing also a tooth and part of an ear. King, of Clifton Forge, vice-president George N. Conrad, treasurer, and Julian A. Burruss, secretary. The blaze, which is supposed to have started from a bolt heating furnace, destroyed the ma chine, blacksmith and woodwork sheds. Young Mens Christian Association to make ar rangements for a religious census of the city for use by the Bible schools of the city. Nearly all of the Prot estant schools of the city will aid iD I the enumeration. document.text: A 6,000 monument will be erected at Salem Church, in Spottsylvania County, at an early date to the memory of the Twenty-third New Jersey Regiment, of which Gen. E. Byrd Grubb was the colo nel during the Civil War. The appro priation for the monument has been made by the State Legislature of New Jersey and the ground on which it will be erected was purchased and donated by Colonel Grubb. Mr. John T. Lester Ruffner, who has been on trial in the Circuit Court of Page County, was given a one-year sentence in the peniten tiary for the attempted murder of his ousin, David Ruffner, about four months ago, at which time the prisoner shot and killed his uncle, Isaac P. Ruffner. For the murder of his uncle Ruffner was given two years in the States prison. The Electoral Board of Richmond, composed of Messrs. F. C. Ebel, W. T. Hancock and Samuel Cohen, through its president, Mr. Ebel, handed its resig nation to the Clerk of the Hustings Court. Nothing can be learned of the reasons actuating the board until the letter is read by Judge Witt, who is out of the city on a fishing trip. It is thought that it is prompted by the allegations made during the grand jury investiga tion of the municipal primary. It is rumored that the members of the board would have resigned some months ago, but were restrained by the advice of friends to wait until the discussion had ceased. The Roanoke City Council and Board of Aldermen held special sessions and voted to offer 250 reward for the ar rest and conviction of the murderer of cx-City Sergeant J. B. Traynham. They also voted to allow the police Jorce 100 for contingencies to be used at the dis- cression of the Mayor. A letter was read from Governor Swanson to the ef fect that he would supplement any re ward offered by the city, and Osceola Lodge, Knights of Pythias, voted a re ward of 100. Much interest was aroused at the Cap itol by the circulation among members of the General Assembly of a pamphlet of 100 pages compiled by Judge George L. Christian to show that his son, W il liam B. Christian, Rowland P. Eubank and Julian M. Sailey were done a gross injustice by the faculty of the Virginia Polytechnic Institute in being denied matriculation because of their alleged connection with hazing. A bill had been introduced looking into intervention by the General Assembly on behalf of these young men. The pamphlet is a very interesting paper, and parts of it are spicy. Judge Christian characterizes l he course of the faculty is illegal, un just and improper. United States Sen ator John W, Daniel, in a long and strong letter in behalf of young Chris tian, says There is not a convict in the penitentiary today who did not have a fairer trial. There is not a citizen out of the penitentiary who would put him self, with respect to property, character or civil rights, in the hands of such an unfair procedure as was held at the in stitute. A hole about three feet wide was blown out of the Courthouse just be hind the judges seat. Judge Moffett had just granted bail to Fred Hoback. who secured a new trial through the Supreme Court for the killing of John L. Jett, a hotel-keeper, over a year ago. Hoback was sentenced to eight years in the State penitentiary, but the verdict oi the lower court was set aside. Hoback was a rural letter carrier and was re turning from a trip when he and Jett met in front of the Courthouse and a difficulty ensued, in which Hoback was seriously cut screral times, after which he shot Jett, killing him instantly. Auld, a Richmond sales man, was thrown from a buggy and pain fully hurt, among his injuries being a broken arm and the almost compete sev erance of one ear. H. P. This meeting will be held July 25, at the American Legion Home. The local Legion is sponsoring a junior baseball team this year, and the games will be played on Wed nesday evenings at the Town Ball Park.
